header_summary:
Tom Briar and Andrew Poelstra have developed a Compressed Transaction Schema to reduce blockchain transaction sizes, focusing on using a block height and index combination instead of standard output information for transaction inputs. The schema is efficient for environments with limited bandwidth, like steganography or satellite communication, by utilizing four main compression strategies and emphasizing public key recovery for compact transactions. The blog post linked offers an in-depth look at the schema, displaying its benefits in bandwidth conservation through examples of uncompressed versus compressed transactions.

Anthony Towns has highlighted two Bitcoin development proposals, CheckTemplateVerify (CTV) and AssumeUTXO (APO), aimed at enhancing wallet and layer-two applications and rethinking the consensus change process. AssumeUTXO, which allows for additional inputs in transactions, has spurred debate around the benefits of fixed input numbers for reducing third-party interference and txid malleability issues. For more technical details, interested parties can reference the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals repository.

Peter Todd has pointed out the significance of CHECKSIG in Lightning Network's anchor channels for maintaining transaction security and has called into question the potential benefits of V3 transactions over existing protocols. His preliminary assessment indicates that V3 transactions may offer minimal improvements and could introduce unnecessary complexity. For further exploration and contribution to these discussions, Todd invites contact through his website and email, providing access to additional resources and insights.

active_posts.title: Future of the bitcoin-dev mailing list
active_posts.summary:
- The Linux Foundation will stop hosting Bitcoin-dev, impacting communication among developers.
- Moderators suggest decentralized archival via public-inbox and Bitcoin blockchain integration.
- Community feedback is sought on platform migration, considering options like Google Groups.

active_posts.title: Ordinal Inscription Size Limits
active_posts.summary:

- They suggest a size limit for blockchain inscriptions akin to OP_RETURN.

active_posts.title: Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal integrates Lamport Scheme with ECC for byte-efficient blockchain transactions.
- Non-publishing of a preimage triggers penalties, ensuring transaction integrity and miner compensation.
- Implementing Argon2 for hashing could shrink signatures to 24 bytes, enhancing blockchain economy.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bech32m BIP: new checksum, and usage for segwit address
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Pieter Wuille proposed a BIP for new segwit address checksums, Bech32m.
- Bech32m is for version 1 and higher, altering the current BIP173.
- Community feedback is sought; discussions are on the Linux Foundation mailing list.
today_in_history_posts.combined_summary:
- Pieter compared Bech32 checksum's error detection to hash functions, noting Bech32's specificity.
- Bech32m was introduced in BIP proposals to improve checksums for native segwit addresses v1+.
- Nakagawa and Pieter discussed BECH32M_CONST generation and error detection enhancements.

today_in_history_posts.title: PoDLEs revisited
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Lloyd Fournier investigates a dual funding Lightning protocol securing user UTXOs with DLEQ proofs.
- Proposals aim to prevent malicious griefing without forcing honest users to spend UTXOs prematurely.
- While PoDLE enhances security by blacklisting, an alternative protocol offers similar safeguards without gossip messages.
today_in_history_posts.combined_summary:
- Taproot maintains private channel privacy, not affecting a stated heuristic involving public channels.
- Rusty Russell explores PoDLE's effectiveness in mitigating parallel and sequential UTXO attacks.
- Lloyd Fournier suggests immediate h2 broadcast in PoDLE to counteract parallel attack vulnerability.
